channel.title: home on achinth
channel.description: Recent content in home on achinth

item.title: what does it mean to be Canadian?
item.description:
Last week, I had a riveting discussion for an hour with Brendan Samek on the Build Canada Discord server. This was arguably the most thought-provoking discussion I’ve had with anyone in recent memory.

Brendan, the ever-present host of the call, asked me a two-part question that really got my gears turning. it was a simple one:

what does Canada mean to you? what does it mean to be Canadian?

Even though I was able to give my visceral, albeit poorly strung, thoughts on the matter, this question forced me to reconcile my relationship with my country, and I’m extremely glad to share with you, the most refined interface I have with my sense of nationalism.

item.title: zohran mamdani, and being priced out of your own economy
item.description:
Zohran Mamdani is the mayor-elect for New York City.

I had my doubts that he was going to win. It was unfathomable to me that a financial centre so focused on the idea of winning (in the capitalist sense) was capable of entertaining a democratic socialist. I stand happily corrected, and extremely proud that he has won the election. His win and agenda here are a paradigm shift of the priorities of the electorate. So, I think the first question to as is: What changed?

item.title: my own, personal political platform
item.description:
TL;DR:

Pragmatic, not performative. Outcomes, not actions.

Canadian federal politics has become performative. The Spring 2025 election was a relative breath of fresh air when compared to the elections that we had in 2021, 2019 and 2015. Reader, I know what you’re thinking.

“Wow! He’s just cherrypicking the elections where the Liberals won and the Conservatives lost! He just wants Stephen Harper back! Fuck this guy!”

Yeah, no. I am a market social democrat. I have only ever voted for the NDP and the Liberals (thanks to the collapse of the NDP in 2025).

item.title: why I don't think I'd make a good parent
item.description:
I was raised, and have good parents. My father is the best father in the world.

I have the greatest examples of ideal parenting from my mother and father. If I can be half as good as a parent as they collectively were; then I think any child I raise would grow to being a formidable, self-sufficient and healthy adult. So why do I think I wouldn’t make for beign a good father? I went and asked my own - and he said (paraphrased from Kannada):

item.title: the prisoner's dilemma is the worst parable for real-life collaboration
item.description:
tl; dr: individual rationality is a really, really bad delineator for both individual and collective decision making.

why prisoner’s dilemma?

The prisoner’s dilemma is used as a motif for

payoff and imprisonment under the typical game theory setup

In the typical prisoner’s dilemma setup, you have two prisoners being interrogated at the same time for a crime they are accused of. Each prisoner has a choice - either rat out to the prosecution (which we will call ‘defection’), or stay silent and do nothing (which we will call ‘cooperation’). However - the prosecution is smart. In order to incentivize an outcome from both of the prisoners, this is the decision space they offer to them. Each number here represents the years that they spend in prison.

item.title: my application to the recurse centre
item.description:
In the interest of sharing my internal loci of control to the rest of the world and to tell you peopke that I really did are about what’s going on - here’s what I said for my Recurse Centre application for the winter batch of 2025-26.

What is the most fascinating thing you’ve learned in the past month?

This doesn’t have to be about programming.

The AI 2027 scenario’s treatment of model specifications made me realize something concrete about why current alignment approaches fail from a circuits perspective.

item.title: on american exceptionalism, sriram and immigration
item.description: I was enjoying solitude on Christmas eve, when I came across this tweet:

item.title: [PART 1] circuit discovery: what the hell is it?
item.description:
This is part one of a series of posts about learning biased circuits in vision/language models. I want to publish a paper to ICML at the end of this.

Like most people, I don’t know anything about this entire sub-field. It’s exhausting, humbling and most of all - exciting to learn something new about how we can understand generative models.

Thanks to perplexity, I get to learn what this subfield is. Let’s get started.

item.title: Hi!
item.description:
This year, has been the darkest of my life so far. I lost my job. I lost some dear friends. I lost hope. I herniated my back. I moved back home. In the pursuit of the things I accomplished, I forgot who I was supposed to be.

So I forced myself to think more about what I’m doing here. I started writing my thoughts which felt disgustingly difficult at first. My self-confidence has never been lower, and if I don’t get comfortable with myself again, I will end up falling deeper into the hole I’ve been living in for the past six months.

item.title: Markdown Syntax Guide
item.description: This article offers a sample of basic Markdown syntax that can be used in Hugo content files, also it shows whether basic HTML elements are decorated with CSS in a Hugo theme.
